stem: A client taking sertraline and recently started on tramadol visits the clinic. Highlight the findings that are most consistent with serotonin syndrome.
passage: The client reports feeling [agitated and restless] since starting the new medication. Upon assessment, the nurse notes [profuse diaphoresis]. Vital signs reveal a [temperature of 102.4Â°F], [heart rate of 118 beats/min], and [blood pressure of 162/94 mmHg]. Physical exam shows [hyperreflexia] and [spontaneous muscle clonus] in the lower extremities. The nurse observes [shivering and tremors] during the interview. The client reports [abdominal cramping and diarrhea]. When checking the eyes, the nurse notes [dilated pupils] (mydriasis). The client is [increasingly confused] and [disoriented to time].

rationale.correct: Serotonin syndrome results from excess serotonin. Cues are categorized into: 1. Mental status changes (agitation, confusion, disorientation). 2. Autonomic hyperactivity (fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, mydriasis, diarrhea). 3. Neuromuscular abnormalities (hyperreflexia, clonus, tremors, shivering). The combination of an SSRI (sertraline) and tramadol (which has serotonergic properties) is a classic drug-drug interaction cause.
rationale.incorrect: The specific medications mentioned (sertraline and tramadol) are the causes/context, not the findings of the syndrome itself.
rationale.clinicalPearls: Treatment involves discontinuing all serotonergic agents and providing supportive care (fluid, cooling, benzodiazepines). Cyproheptadine (a serotonin antagonist) may be used.
rationale.questionTrap: Clonus and hyperreflexia are hallmark signs that help distinguish Serotonin Syndrome from Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (which has 'lead-pipe' rigidity).

reviewUnits.heading: Serotonin Syndrome Symptoms
reviewUnits.body: Remember 'HARM': Hyperthermia, Autonomic instability, Rigidity (less common than clonus), Mental status changes.

answerBreakdown.label: Critical Cues
answerBreakdown.content: The identified evidence represents objective clinical markers of physiological instability.
